Situation1: They send an occasional text to check in with their parents over the weekend.
Situation2: They conduct an in-depth consultation with a patient taking multiple high-risk medications to prevent dangerous interactions.
Story: My phone buzzed in my pocket just as I was about to start a medication review with Mrs. Lee, a patient who’d just been prescribed a complicated regimen. I glanced at the screen—Mom. The text was simple: “How are you? Haven’t heard from you this weekend.” Guilt pricked at me. I knew she worried if I didn’t check in, especially since Dad’s health had started to decline. But Mrs. Lee was waiting, her bag of pill bottles clutched tightly, her eyes anxious. As a pharmacist, I was expected to give her my full attention, to catch any dangerous interactions and explain everything clearly. But as a child, I was supposed to reassure my parents, to be present even from afar. My mind raced, torn between the duty to my patient and the responsibility to my family. I could feel the weight of both roles pressing in, each demanding something I wasn’t sure I could give at the same time.
